text: BR17120 Genetics, Evolution and Diversity Jo Hamilton (e-mail: jvh) Introduction  Module learning outcomes  How is the module run?  Assessment  Books  Navigating our module on Blackboard  Module timetable Objectives and learning outcomes. On successful completion of this module students should be able to:  Describe genetic processes at all levels of organisation (e.g. molecular, chromosomal, population) with reference to appropriate structures and concepts.  Carry out genetic experiments in the laboratory, using appropriate equipment and techniques, and analyse and interpret the resulting data.  Outline the key phases in the evolution of life on Earth, describe the evolution of major groups of organisms and identify the anatomical links between extinct and living life forms. Objectives and learning outcomes. On successful completion of this module students should be able to:  Compare and contrast the morphology and anatomy of the major groups, be able to identify representatives of the groups and describe their key features and physiological adaptations in the context of environmental conditions.  Explain how different biological classification systems are defined and used and describe the diversity and evolutionary history of a taxon of organisms through the construction of a basic phylogenetic tree and accompanying narrative. How is the module run?  Weekly learning folders on Blackboard – 3 lectures per week (4 lectures in last week of term – summary and revision)  2 x 3 hour lab practicals – 2 x 1 hour data analysis workshops  2 x 2 hour computer-based practicals – 2 x 1 hour coursework support workshop How is the module run?  Module specific schedule on Blackboard & timetable on Student Record – N.B. Check your practical allocations on your Student Record. How will I be assessed?  1 mid-term Blackboard Quiz – Linkage, Recombination & Gene Expression (25% module mark)  1 coursework assessment: – Construction of a phylogenetic tree & narrative (1500 words, 25% module mark)  End of Semester MCQ exam (50% module mark) Image from: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tree_of_life_(biology) What books do we suggest?
